body.p: Hookworm infection is common in tropical and subtropical areas and is caused by soil-transmitted nematodes.1,2 Two species of hookworm, Ancylostoma duodenale and Nicrophorus americanus, form infection in humans. A duodenale is found in Europe, Asia, China, Japan, India, and Pacific Islands, whereas N americanus is found in America and Caribbean, Africa, Asia, and the Pacific Islands.3

A 7-year-old boy was admitted to the emergency clinic with abdominal pain. He had a history of fallen stone on his abdomen while he was climbing on a wall. On admission physical examination revealed abdominal tenderness, rigidity, and defense. Laboratory test results showed hemoglobin 11.4 g/dL, white cell count 10 700/mm3, and platelet count 322 000/mm3. Biochemical test results were within normal limits. The patient underwent emergency surgery with a preoperative diagnosis of intestinal perforation. The surgeon observed a 10-cm defect on the ileal mesentery and 3 perforation site in the ileum during the exploration. A segmental ileal resection was performed. Gross examination of the ileal segment displayed multiple small white worms of 8 to 10 mm in length in the intestinal lumen. No perforation was found. Microscopic examination of the specimen revealed hookworms attached to the intestinal mucosa (Figure 1). Hookworms had 4 ventral teeth consistent with A duodenale (Figure 2).

caption.p: Light microscopy showing a hookworm attached to the ileal mucosa (hematoxylin and eosin, 100×)
Photomicrograph of the ventral part of the hookworm showing 4 teeth (arrows) consistent with Ancylostoma duodenale (hematoxylin and eosin, 400×)

body.p: Hookworms usually infect the human by penetrating the skin. Six weeks after initial infection worms reach to the gastrointestinal tract and attack the mucosa by the buccal capsule in the small intestine. Hookworm infection is usually asymptomatic; however, it can cause anemia and hypoproteinemia. The worm may cause blood loss, which can lead to development of iron deficiency anemia. Eosinophilia has been noted in 30% to 60% of infected patients. The diagnosis of hookworm infection is usually made by direct microscopic examination of the stool. However, the 2 species cannot be distinguished on the basis of the egg morphology. The major difference between these species is that N americanus has 2 cutting plates whereas A duodenale has 4 teeth.3,4
We report an unusual case of intestinal A duodenale infection diagnosed incidentally by intestinal resection due to an unrelated cause.
